summary: An FBI communication from Miami to Los Angeles requesting an interview with Michael D. Friedman and another individual (name redacted) regarding their employment with Jeffrey Epstein. The document details an obstruction of justice case against a former Epstein butler who attempted to sell victim information, and notes that Friedman and the other individual may have witnessed Epstein's interactions with underage girls.

persons.name: Michael D. Friedman
persons.role: Potential witness, former employee of Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Former housekeeper or property manager for Jeffrey Epstein at an unspecified property. The FBI seeks to interview him regarding any observations of Epstein's interactions with underage girls.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The subject of a child prostitution investigation. He entered a non-prosecution agreement, pled guilty to state offenses, served prison time, and completed community supervision in July 2010. Civil suits were filed against him by victims.

connections.description: Friedman previously worked for Epstein as a housekeeper or property manager at one of his properties.

events.title: FBI Investigation of Epstein Begins
events.description: Miami Division began investigating Jeffrey Epstein for child prostitution.

events.title: Obstruction of Justice Case Opened
events.description: Miami Division opened an obstruction of justice case against a former Epstein butler/house manager who attempted to sell lists of additional victims for $50,000.

events.title: Attempt to Sell Victim Information
events.description: The former Epstein butler attempted to sell victim information to an Undercover Employee (UCE) for $50,000.

events.title: Epstein Completes Supervision
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein completed his state-mandated community supervision as a registered sex offender.

keyFacts: A former butler/house manager for Jeffrey Epstein attempted to sell lists of additional Epstein victims for $50,000 in November 2009, leading to an FBI obstruction of justice case.

Michael D. Friedman and another individual (name redacted) are former Epstein employees (housekeepers/property managers) sought for interview as they may have witnessed Epstein's interactions with underage girls.
Jeffrey Epstein maintained residences in multiple locations: New York, NY; Palm Beach, FL; U.S. Virgin Islands; New Mexico; London, England; and Paris, France.
Epstein's victims filed civil suits against him in state and federal court seeking damages.
The document is an FBI communication (likely a lead or request for investigation) from the Miami office to the Los Angeles office regarding interviewing potential witnesses in California.
